hints_html:
The substitution \(u = x^2\) almost works...

For an alternative solution, use a trigonometric substitution.
hints_latex: For an alternative solution, use a trigonometric substitution.
hints_raw:
The substitution <math> u = x^2</math> almost works...
For an alternative solution, use a trigonometric substitution.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
For the change of variable \(u = 1 + x^2\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle du = 2x \, dx.\end{aligned}\]

So

\[\begin{aligned} x^3 \sqrt{1+x^2} dx = x^2 \sqrt{1+x^2} \, x \, dx = x^2 \sqrt{u} \, \frac{du}{2}\end{aligned}\]

To write the remaining \(x^2\) in terms of \(u\), we note that since \(u = 1 + x^2\) we have \(x^2 = u-1\). Thus

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^3 \sqrt{1+x^2} dx &= \int (u-1) \sqrt{u} \, \frac{du}{2} \\ &= \int (u-1) u^{1/2} \, \frac{du}{2} \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \int (u^{3/2} - u^{1/2}) du \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{2}{5} u^{5/2} - \frac{2}{3} u^{3/2} \right) + C \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{2}{5} (1+x^2)^{5/2} - \frac{2}{3} (1+x^2)^{3/2} \right) + C \\ &= \frac{1}{5} (1+x^2)^{5/2} - \frac{1}{3} (1+x^2)^{3/2} + C.\end{aligned}\]

This integral could be done with a trig substitution as well. We notice inside the square root that we have \(1+x^2\). This motivates a substitution

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x=\tan(\theta)\end{aligned}\]

so that we can make use of the identity

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}1+\tan^2\theta=\sec^2\theta.\end{aligned}\]

With this substitution we also have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\textrm{d}x=\sec^2\theta\textrm{d}\theta.\end{aligned}\]

Putting this into our integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int{}x^3\sqrt{1+x^2}\textrm{d}x &= \int{}\tan^3\theta\sqrt{\sec^2\theta}\sec^2\theta\textrm{d}\theta \\ &= \int\tan^3\theta\sec^3\theta\textrm{d}\theta\end{aligned}\]

where we have used the identity from above. This trig integral is of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \int\tan^m\theta\sec^n\theta\textrm{d}\theta\end{aligned}\]

with m and n odd. We want to write this in a form that we can easily integrate. If we let \(\displaystyle {}u=\sec\theta\) then we have hope because we notice the derivative \(\displaystyle {}\sec\theta\tan\theta\) is also there. Making this substitution with

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\textrm{d}u=\sec\theta\tan\theta\textrm{d}\theta\end{aligned}\]

we get

\[\begin{aligned} \int{}\tan^3\theta\sec^3\theta\textrm{d}\theta &= \int{}\tan^2\theta(\tan\theta\sec\theta)\sec^2\theta\textrm{d}\theta \\ &=\int(\sec^2\theta-1)\sec^2\theta(\tan\theta\sec\theta)\textrm{d}\theta \\ &=\int(u^2-1)u^2\textrm{d}u=\int{}u^4-u^2\textrm{d}u \\ &=\frac{1}{5}u^5-\frac{1}{3}u^3+C.\end{aligned}\]

We now have to substitute back,

\[\begin{aligned} u=\sec\theta=\sec\arctan{x}=\sqrt{x^2+1}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we get

\[\begin{aligned} \int{}x^3\sqrt{x^2+1}\textrm{d}x = \frac{1}{5}\left(\sqrt{x^2+1}\right)^5-\frac{1}{3}\left(\sqrt{x^2+1}\right)^3+C\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
For the change of variable  <math> u = 1 + x^2 </math>, we have
:<math>\displaystyle du = 2x \, dx. </math>

So

:<math>
x^3 \sqrt{1+x^2} dx = x^2 \sqrt{1+x^2} \, x \, dx = x^2 \sqrt{u} \, \frac{du}{2}
</math>

To write the remaining <math> x^2 </math> in terms of <math> u </math>, we note that since <math> u = 1 + x^2 </math> we have <math> x^2 = u-1 </math>.  Thus

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int x^3 \sqrt{1+x^2} dx 
&= \int (u-1) \sqrt{u} \, \frac{du}{2} \\
&= \int (u-1) u^{1/2} \, \frac{du}{2} \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \int (u^{3/2} - u^{1/2}) du \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{2}{5} u^{5/2} - \frac{2}{3} u^{3/2} \right) + C \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{2}{5} (1+x^2)^{5/2} - \frac{2}{3} (1+x^2)^{3/2} \right) + C \\
&= \frac{1}{5} (1+x^2)^{5/2} - \frac{1}{3} (1+x^2)^{3/2} + C.
\end{align}
</math>
This integral could be done with a trig substitution as well. We notice inside the square root that we have <math>1+x^2</math>.  This motivates a substitution

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x=\tan(\theta)
</math>

so that we can make use of the identity

:<math>
\displaystyle{}1+\tan^2\theta=\sec^2\theta.
</math>

With this substitution we also have

:<math>
\displaystyle{}\textrm{d}x=\sec^2\theta\textrm{d}\theta.
</math>

Putting this into our integral

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int{}x^3\sqrt{1+x^2}\textrm{d}x &= \int{}\tan^3\theta\sqrt{\sec^2\theta}\sec^2\theta\textrm{d}\theta \\
&= \int\tan^3\theta\sec^3\theta\textrm{d}\theta
\end{align}
</math>

where we have used the identity from above.  This trig integral is of the form

:<math>
\int\tan^m\theta\sec^n\theta\textrm{d}\theta
</math>

with ''m'' and ''n'' odd.  We want to write this in a form that we can easily integrate.  If we let <math>\displaystyle{}u=\sec\theta</math> then we have hope because we notice the derivative <math>\displaystyle{}\sec\theta\tan\theta</math> is also there.  Making this substitution with

:<math>
\displaystyle{}\textrm{d}u=\sec\theta\tan\theta\textrm{d}\theta
</math>

we get

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int{}\tan^3\theta\sec^3\theta\textrm{d}\theta &= \int{}\tan^2\theta(\tan\theta\sec\theta)\sec^2\theta\textrm{d}\theta \\
&=\int(\sec^2\theta-1)\sec^2\theta(\tan\theta\sec\theta)\textrm{d}\theta \\
&=\int(u^2-1)u^2\textrm{d}u=\int{}u^4-u^2\textrm{d}u \\
&=\frac{1}{5}u^5-\frac{1}{3}u^3+C.
\end{align}
</math>

We now have to substitute back,

:<math>
u=\sec\theta=\sec\arctan{x}=\sqrt{x^2+1}.
</math>

Therefore we get

:<math>
\int{}x^3\sqrt{x^2+1}\textrm{d}x = \frac{1}{5}\left(\sqrt{x^2+1}\right)^5-\frac{1}{3}\left(\sqrt{x^2+1}\right)^3+C
</math>
statement_html:
Evaluate the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^3\sqrt{1 + x^2} dx\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Evaluate the integral

:<math> \int x^3\sqrt{1 + x^2} dx </math>
